subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... So for each word, you are recommending I replace ing with QS N. Can I safely write code that finds the string ing and replaces it with QS N, or
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> <mailto:Read_Alphabet%40yahoogroups.com>, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > My personal view on this one is that all -ing endings, including
> > verbal ones (bathing, thinking), nominal ones (shirting, stuffing
> > (as in what you put in a turkey)), and root ones (nothing) should be
> > written without a vowel except as needed to resolve ambiguity.
> > Read clearly uses It in all these words, but there are plenty
> > who use Eat, or who vary between one and the other, or who use
> > an intermediate sound. This is another neutralization, but unlike
> > the t/d and It/Et-before-nasals, it occurs in all accents --
> > there are no English words ending in -eeng or -eang or the like.
> >
>
> This is an interesting proposal; I suppose the suggestion amounts to this:
>
> use #21Ing for:
> 1. the sounds of /N/ (this is the QM rule)
> 2. the sounds of Lexical Set KIT + /N/
> 3. the sounds of Lexical Set FLEECE + /N/
>
> I would also like to add:
> 4. the sound /N/+/g/
>
> I suggest #4 because 1.in practice most people will rarely distinguish
> "finger" and "sing" and 2. I know of no case where it is necessary to
> indicate that difference in writing and 3. the /Nk/ is more obvious
> and less error prone than /N/+/g/ and can be still be written as Ing+Key
>

So for each word, you are recommending I replace "ing" with QS "N." Can
I safely write code that finds the string "ing" and replaces it with QS
"N," or should I look for a base word before doing so? That is, in the
first case, I simply change all "ing" to "N." In the second case, I find
the word "jumping." I look to see if there is a word "jump", and finding
that, replace it with QS "N."

I realize there is a third possibility, that I first convert words like
"jumping" to QS, so it would look like "JampiN." Then I replace the
pattern "iN" with "N." Likewise, I can replace the pattern "IN" with
"N," and "gN" with N. I guess that would be the best way.

How about the "ed" endings? Should these all be changed to "d"?

Paul
